info.game_comments:
Stefan Goodreau game 1.
Champion Update #6: David Madden.

(1, 1).clue: Monday is named for this, first visited by man 40 years ago today

(2, 1).clue: Voted most popular at her East Nashville high school, in the '80s, she'd become the talk of the town

(3, 1).clue: For the sake of convenience & brevity, this 19th c. author signed his early essays "RLS"

(4, 1).clue: He was the last one who also served as a U.S. president

(5, 1).clue: In 1967 John Lennon appeared on the cover of the first issue of this music magazine

(6, 1).clue: Tomatoes are frequently grown in one of these where the temperature can be controlled

(1, 2).clue: Sensibly, pondeli, the Czech word for Monday, literally means "after" this

(2, 2).clue: In 1994 his California high school voted him "most likely to succeed"; you watch golf?

(3, 2).clue: He wrote his first 2 novels, "A Time to Kill" & "The Firm", while serving in the Mississippi legislature

(4, 2).clue: In 1903 & 1904 he served in the Philippines as a second lieutenant

(5, 2).clue: Warren Buffett topped this mag's 2008 list of billionaires; mayor Bloomberg was its most powerful billionaire in 2009

(6, 2).clue: I prefer to use my key, but you can start a car this way, by short-circuiting the ignition

(1, 3).clue: In a nursery rhyme, "Monday's child is fair of" this

(2, 3).clue: At her New York high school in 1999, she was voted most likely to appear on "Jeopardy!"; we'd love to have her

(3, 3).clue: In the 1940s this writer created his "three laws of robotics" for use in his stories

(4, 3).clue: He was the man with a plan named for him

(5, 3).clue: The name of this food magazine is a French phrase often said before dining

(6, 3).clue: Flapjacks, come & get 'em under this name!

(1, 4).clue: Not just a bad day for the stock market, it's the Monday after the last day of the NFL season, when coaches get fired

(2, 4).clue: At her Virginia high school, this "Speed" star was voted "most likely to brighten your day"

(3, 4).clue: His "True at First Light", about an African safari, was published in 1999, 38 years after his suicide

(4, 4).clue: The fifth star was a reward for his service in World War I & he retired at that rank in 1924

(5, 4).clue: This mag now distributed with the Sunday paper debuted in 1941, subtitled "The Weekly Picture Newspaper"

(6, 4).clue: This Arkansas city has been called the "Baden-Baden of America"

(1, 5).clue: The U.S. declared war on Japan on this Monday in 1941

(2, 5).clue: At his Longview, Texas high school in 1988, this actor was voted most handsome

(3, 5).clue: Written in Portuguese, "O Alquimista" by Paulo Coelho has sold 30 mil. copies, many under this English title

(4, 5).clue: In 1949 he became the first Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff

(5, 5).clue: "Life made easier" is the motto of the magazine called "Real" this

(6, 5).clue: Launched by Wired magazine in 1996, this early search engine was later acquired by Lycos

(1, 1).clue: You might have to window shop in this Swiss city's elegant Bahnhofstrasse: prices are lethal there

(3, 1).clue: This U.S. state where you're the official marine mammal

(4, 1).clue: Robert Ripley's 1st "Believe It or Not!" had sports oddities like "A. Forrester...ran 100 yards" this way in 14 seconds

(5, 1).clue: I saw 3 of these objects, first reported near Mt. Rainier in June 1947, hovering over my house last night

(6, 1).clue: In "The Wizard of Oz", Glinda was a good one

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from The Hague in the Netherlands.)  This upper house of the Dutch Parliament meets here; like this corresponding U.S. body used to be, it's selected indirectly rather than directly by the people

(4, 2).clue: Ripley Castle in this nation has been home to the Ingilby family for 700 years & 26 generations

(5, 2).clue: My luggage was lost & I'm convinced it's now in this region named for a British Atlantic isle

(6, 2).clue: Mesmerizing, like the Greek god of sleep

(1, 3).clue: Marcel Proust is buried in this vast Parisian cemetery

(3, 3).clue: This continent, for the species Trichechus senegalensis

(4, 3).clue: You can actually sleep with the fishes at Ripley's Aquarium in Myrtle Beach in this state

(5, 3).clue: Last time I was fishing in Scotland I hooked this large, ancient plesiosaur & she got away with my best lure

(6, 3).clue: From a method of shining army shoes, this word is paired with "polish" to mean extreme cleanliness

(1, 4).clue: Its name is from a jebal, or mount, named for Tariq ibn Zizad, the general who led the Muslim conquest of Spain

(3, 4).clue: Moises the Manatee's home, this island commonwealth

(4, 4).clue: Ornithologist S. Dillon Ripley served as the head of this D.C. institution from 1964 to 1984

(5, 4).clue: Hold onto your bug spray--I saw one of these insect/human creatures Richard Gere sought in a movie

(6, 4).clue: Adjective meaning tediously repetitive... or repetitious... or lacking in variety

(1, 5).clue: Steg & Schaan are towns in this landlocked principality

(3, 5).clue: The wetlands of this Mexican state, also the home of the Zapatistas

(4, 5).clue: On June 6, 1849 Major Ripley Arnold founded what became this city near Dallas

(5, 5).clue: I saw one of these hare/antelope hybrids in Johnny's dressing room just now & he called it by name!

(6, 5).clue: It's reparation made by giving compensation for damages

(0, 0).clue: Longfellow began a poem about this earlier poet, "Tuscan, that wanderest through the realms of gloom"
